results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 67]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures a Surf Life Saving Carnival at Trigg Beach near Perth, Western Australia, Easter 1979.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:52:00 the Gadsden business name advertised as a sponsor on the side of a rubber boat

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 58]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures Gadsden family gatherings at the poolside and for a Christmas party at their Toorak, Melbourne home in the 1970s.

There are some great examples of 1970s style fashion trends and hair styles across the generations and a view into the family’s life at home, such as enjoying their backyard pool. Unusually, filmmaker Ron himself is filmed handing out the presents at the Christmas party.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 scenes of family floating the pool in the family garden
00:00:40:00 an array of fashion of the era
00:00:58:00 a beer moment
00:01:28:00 Ron Gadsden in a 1970s style cravat
00:02:46:00 Ron distributes Christmas presents
00:03:41:00 Jess Gadsden in the pool

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 57]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures a trip on the ‘Paddle Steamer Emmylou’ along the Murray River, NSW and Victoria, in 1982.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 Jess Gadsden and companions having lunch on the deck of the ‘Emmylou’
00:00:28:00 houses appear on on the riverbank
00:03:13:00 the ‘Emmylou’ flag being explained to passengers
00:03:14:00 buffet 1970s style
00:03:55:00 ‘Paddle Steamer Emmylou’ in full view
00:14:41:00 Jess Gadsden standing on the bank, looking at a weir on the Murray and waving at the camera
00:09:38:00 passengers assisting with loading wood onto the ‘Emmylou’

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 42]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is a composite of Gadsden family life in 1983 and 1984 at home at their farm and in Toorak.

Firstly, children of the family on their ponies and horses at the farm are being guided by Jess Gadsden. We then see first birthday celebrations for baby Nicko, one of the Gadsden grandchildren. There is also a Christmas party in the garden of Ron and Jess Gadsden’s Toorak home in Melbourne.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:02:14:00 baby Nicko with the birthday cake

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 39]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the Gadsdens gathering at Surfers Paradise in Queensland, for Easter in 1987. We see swimming and general beach activity, surfing and paddling in the waves. There is an Easter egg hunt in the holiday house yard and we also see the a barbeque on a 1970s three-legged hotplate and beers being drunk from ‘stubby holders’.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:07:03:00 cooking on a 1970s three-legged barbeque

This film shows sailing activities at the Davey’s Bay Yacht Club as well as yacht racing off the Mornington Peninsula, Victoria.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

00:01:05:00 yacht sailing into bay with cliff top houses in background

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 34]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the Gadsdens at Thredbo and Perisher, ski resorts in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. They and their friends are having fun in very snowy conditions on the slopes, coming and going from their accommodation, the ski lifts, throwing snowballs and wearing examples of circa 1969 skiing outfits. Indoor scenes give an indication of everyday life on these holidays, such as using a fondue set at the dinner table, joking around for the camera whilst preparing for bed and some holiday knitting. There are views of the majestic mountain scenery and of the townships.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:15:00 snow vehicle with passengers
00:05:30:00 views of the accommodation indicate the depth of the snow and the general snowy conditions
00:11:56:00 one of the Gadsden daughters enjoys a quiet moment of knitting
00:12:30:00 an example of 1970s style fondue sharing at the table
00:13:08:00 Jess Gadsden in the kitchen.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel opens with the title ‘Surfers Paradise May 1975’ written in the sand between waves. The subtitle ‘Passing Parade’ shows the filmmakers intention: life on the beach on the Gold Coast at the time. The reel begins with early morning scenes of both the beach and the duplex holiday house situated right on the sand. We see lots of surfing – board surfing, body surfing and a longboard with paddles. We also see a large jellyfish in the sand, frisbee playing, strolling along the sand in 1970s fashion flares, Gadsdens running in a group along the beach, family members fishing, a commercial fishing boat in the waves, knitting on a towel on sand, sitting on the house balcony with drinks, a barbeque on the rooftop and views along the coastline.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:56:00 ice cream cart on the beach
00:13:14:00 the filmmaker himself enjoying a XXXX beer while smiling for the camera
00:13:53:00 mid-rise apartment blocks along the coast more sparsely spaced than now

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 36]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows some Geelong Grammar rugby games over June and July, 1972.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.
